quote: I was trying to win the whole race this time. Every time the moto would come by I was like, 'I'm trying to win the overall. That was my goal today.'

I am happy everything went right today after Steamboat. The plan was to go in the break. I went hard on the first dirt climb and went over the top alone. I just held what I knew I could do all day based on heart rate and nobody bridged up. The gap was over 10 minutes at one point.

Going into The Rad, I didn't know what to expect. I was heavily underprepared for the event, but gave it all I had regardless. Unfortunately, I had to be pulled from the race because I missed the second cutoff by just a few minutes.

Just after SBT GRVL in August I had come down with Covid and spend most of the next 7 weeks recovering, not spending much time on the bike. I was unsure of my conditioning going into the Rad but knew that if I rode my ride I'd do fine.
Even though the weather was looking questionable, I was able to finish my first 100 mile ride and beat the rain. Trinidad gravel lived up to all the hype and my legs felt strong throughout the ride.

As the day went on the wind picked up and made for a challenging end of the race, not to mention some gnarly climbs through town to finish downtown at the expo, but we persevered with mostly smiles and high fives.
Downtown Trinidad was completely revitalized from the last time I had been through here many years ago... Usually these little towns go downhill, not up, and it was a welcomed surprise.
The town was overflowing with enthusiasm from more than a thousand of seemingly every type of rider, pros and amateurs alike from 46 states and nine countries.
Seeing familiar faces throughout the day at aid stations, on the road, and at the finish line was also such a cool feeling.
